Help Us Keep a Valuable Community Service!
We are having issues with the misuse of our plastic and paper recycling bins at the Elementary School. The recycling bins have been full of household garbage and cardboard (which is not recyclable) and household garbage has been found lying around the recycling bins. As a result, the school district is being charged fees IN ADDITION to our regular rate because anything and everything is being placed in the recycling bins and therefore it cannot be disposed of as recycling. Unfortunately, if the misuse of the bins continues, we will have to discontinue the recycling service.

Reminder:
The only items allowed in the paper bin are paper and phone books, no shiny print.
The only items allowed in the plastic bin are empty and clean plastic containers.

SA Teachers Earn Scholarships to Travel to Poland
High School English teachers Mr. Tim Smith and Mrs. Kim Piekut have earned scholarships from Classrooms without Borders to travel to Poland in the summer of 2021. These scholarships, which cover all travel and seminar expenses, are designed for teachers to participate in study seminars in Poland that focus on the history of the Holocaust. This seminar enables educators like Mrs. Piekut and Mr. Smith to create classroom programs, activities, units and lesson plans that reflect on the knowledge and experience that they will acquire so their students will be more informed about the causes and outcomes of the Holocaust.

Last year Middle School reading teacher Laura Thomson earned the same scholarship through Classrooms without Borders and traveled to Poland this past summer.

These scholarships, which cover all travel and seminar expenses, are designed for teachers to participate in study seminars in Poland that focus on the history of the Holocaust. This seminar enables educators like Mrs. Piekut and Mr. Smith to create classroom programs, activities, units and lesson plans that reflect on the knowledge and experience that they will acquire so their students will be more informed about the causes and outcomes of the Holocaust.

Last year Middle School reading teacher Laura Thomson earned the same scholarship through Classrooms without Borders and traveled to Poland this past summer.

NEW! Flexible Instruction Days
The PA Department of Education has approved South Allegheny School District’s request to provide “Flexible
Instructional Days” to our learners. This means that on days when situations like winter weather or a building emergency
require us to close our schools, we can provide instruction to our students at home rather than in the classroom (think
“Alternative Snow Day.”)
The state will count this as a full day of school and we will not have to make it up during the school year. The District has
been approved to use up to five (5) of these days this school year. We are planning to use these “Flexible Instructional
Days” throughout the remainder of this school year, as needed.
For more information (a letter to parents and a FAQ page) please go to our website under the News section.

Mollie Kish, an SA Class of 2010 grad, now works as an exploration geoscientist for Shell Exploration and Production Co.

Mollie said that SA prepared her for her current field because SA offered abundant extra curricular activities. She was involved in Cheerleading, Expect Respect, Future Medical Careers Club, Yearbook Committee, National Honor Society, Student Council and Junior Statesman. Being a part of those different organizations early on gave her an idea of what different career paths would be like; which ultimately helped her choose her current profession.

Mollie is based in Houston, TX but her job takes her all over the world, with trips to Scotland, England and Trinidad just this year!

We are proud of you Mollie!
